user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_TaskGetInfo(osal_id_t task_id, OS_task_prop_t *task_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *       record;
    int32                      return_code;
    OS_object_token_t          token;
    OS_task_internal_record_t *task;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(task_prop);

    memset(task_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_task_prop_t));

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, task_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_task_table, token);
        task   = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_task_table, token);

        if (record->name_entry != NULL)
        {
            strncpy(task_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(task_prop->name) - 1);
            task_prop->name[sizeof(task_prop->name) - 1] = 0;
        }
        task_prop->creator    = record->creator;
        task_prop->stack_size = task->stack_size;
        task_prop->priority   = task->priority;

        return_code = OS_TaskGetInfo_Impl(&token, task_prop);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TaskGetInfo:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
int32 OS_TaskGetInfo_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_task_prop_t *task_prop)
{
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_task_table
...
OS_task_internal_record_t OS_task_table[LOCAL_NUM_OBJECTS]
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char            task_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    size_t          stack_size;
    osal_priority_t priority;
    osal_task_entry entry_function_pointer;
    osal_task_entry delete_hook_pointer;
    void *          entry_arg;
    osal_stackptr_t stack_pointer;
} OS_task_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char            name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    osal_id_t       creator;
    size_t          stack_size;
    osal_priority_t priority;
} OS_task_prop_t
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected the provided function and related definitions for constructs that are known compiler-specific language extensions (examples: __attribute__, __asm__, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, label-as-value/goto labels as values, __declspec, inline assembler, #pragma with compiler-specific extensions, anonymous structs/unions if non-standard, GCC statement expressions, or other documented compiler extensions). None of the presented code uses any of these forms. The macros shown (OS_CHECK_POINTER, OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET) expand to standard C expressions; pointer and array operations, sizeof, strncpy, memset, typedefs (int32, osal_id_t, etc.), const pointer declarations (extern OS_common_record_t *const ...), and normal function calls are all standard C and not compiler extensions. Therefore there are no fragments in the provided code that appear to rely on documented compiler language extensions and no further investigation is needed for Rule 1.2 based on the supplied code.
